6.text: - Thanks for having me, thanks for the introduction Tina.

9.text: It's so great to be back on campus.

10.text: I was reflecting yesterday that it has been indeed

13.text: nine years since I took the design class

15.text: that Embrace came out of, so I'm feeling extra old today.

19.text: So I'd like you guys to go through an exercise with me

25.text: and hold out your hands in front of you.

31.text: And imagine what you could place inside your hands.

44.text: What you see here is a premature baby.

46.text: He looks like he's resting peacefully when in fact

48.text: he is struggling to stay alive,

50.text: because he can't regulate his own body temperature.

53.text: Sadly, there are millions of babies like this

55.text: born every year around the world.

57.text: In fact, 15 million pre-term and underweight babies

62.text: Three million babies die in the first 28 days of their life.

70.text: these babies face is staying warm,

72.text: and that is the primary function of an incubator.

75.text: But incubators are expensive, they cost $20,000 upwards,

78.text: they require a constant supply of electricity,

80.text: they're difficult to operate, so you're not going to find

83.text: them in rural areas where many of these babies are dying.

87.text: In 2007 while I was doing my MBA here at Stanford,

90.text: I took a class at the design school that would completely

94.text: Many of you may be familiar with it,

96.text: but Design for Extreme Affordability brings together

98.text: students of all the different graduate programs

101.text: with the goal of creating low-cost technologies for people

103.text: living on less than a dollar a day.

106.text: The challenge posed to my team at the time

108.text: was to build a baby incubator that cost less

110.text: than 1% of the cost of a traditional incubator,

114.text: which in the U.S. is about $20,000.

116.text: So the first thing we did was to go on the ground

119.text: to places like Nepal, and Uganda,

122.text: and this is what we would often see.

125.text: So this is a hospital, neonatal intensive care unit

128.text: Every baby in here is in need of incubation.

131.text: And then you have a donated incubator

133.text: sitting in the corner of the room that's empty.

137.text: There's no electricity to power it,

139.text: no one has been trained on how to use it.

141.text: If a part breaks there are no spare parts for replacement.

145.text: So even when these incubators are free,

148.text: they're not usable because of all these systemic issues.

153.text: Instead people use solutions like this,

155.text: these are old space heaters used to warm babies.

157.text: You put your hand in front of one of these and you'll

159.text: immediately feel it starting to burn.

163.text: These are the most common solution in India,

166.text: where 40% of all the world's premature babies are born.

168.text: But in every clinic I visited

170.text: you hear stories of lightbulbs shattering

172.text: over these babies because of problems with the circuits,

174.text: so completely unsafe and ineffective solutions out there.

178.text: From there we traveled to the villages,

181.text: and that's where I truly began to understand the problem.

183.text: This is Sujatha, this is one of the first women I met

186.text: in a village in South India.

188.text: Sujatha gave birth to her baby two months prematurely.

192.text: She took her baby to a village doctor

194.text: who advised her to go to a city hospital

196.text: so her baby could be placed in an incubator.

198.text: That hospital was over four hours away

201.text: and she didn't have the money to get there.

207.text: And since then I've heard dozens of similar stories.

210.text: But it was based on stories like that that we realized,

212.text: what was needed was not just a lower cost version

214.text: of what exists today, we needed something that could

216.text: function without a constant supply of electricity

219.text: that would be easy enough for a mother or a midwife

222.text: or a healthcare worker in a village setting to use.

225.text: So coming back to Stanford, we went to the drawing board.

227.text: We wanted something super intuitive to use,

230.text: so we created a sleeping bag design.

232.text: These are literally our first sketches of the product

235.text: on the back of a napkin.

237.text: And then we thought what could maintain heat

239.text: at a constant temperature without the need for electricity.

242.text: We went back to high school physics, to the concept

245.text: that when a material changes phases,

247.text: let's say from a solid to a liquid, or a liquid to a solid,

250.text: it does so at one constant temperature.

253.text: What if we could find a material that melted at human body

255.text: temperature, and then put enough of that substance in

258.text: that that melting period took place over hours at a time.

263.text: We didn't know what that material was,

265.text: so we prototyped with the closest thing we could find.

267.text: This is butter in ziplock bags.

269.text: We made quite a mess at the D School.

271.text: From there we went to a Salvation Army,

273.text: and we bought everything baby related we could find

276.text: and literally started duct taping our first

279.text: So if you can see here, our first prototype had a tube

282.text: going down the side of the sleeping bag where you would

285.text: pour the boiling water and that would melt

289.text: Then we showed this to some people and they said to us

291.text: it's probably not a good idea to put boiling water

294.text: right next to a baby's head.

295.text: So we quickly scrapped that and moved on

300.text: Here we realized that babies in these countries

302.text: often don't wear diapers, so we needed something,

304.text: a material that was waterproof and really easy to wipe down.

307.text: Those were the materials we identified here.

311.text: And then with those early prototypes we went back to India,

313.text: showed them to mothers, to doctors,

316.text: to health care workers, and with their feedback

318.text: we continued to iterate on the design.

322.text: We realized the importance of sterility.

324.text: Because these are all reusable we didn't want babies to

326.text: cross-infect each other if they were sick.

328.text: So we ended up creating this sleeping bag out of one

331.text: entire piece of fabric where there are limited seams

333.text: on the inside where dirt can collect.

336.text: Here doctors requested a clear viewing window so they

339.text: could observe the baby's breathing and color more easily.

343.text: And then this was one of my favorite stories.

346.text: So on the wax pouch, there is a temperature indicator.

349.text: It's a liquid crystal display that changes color

353.text: so you know when it's too hot or too cold.

355.text: And as we showed this to the mothers in villages,

359.text: They would say to us, we don't trust Western medicine.

363.text: If you gave me a dosage of medicine for my baby.

365.text: I would cut it in half because it's too strong.

368.text: So if you told me to keep this at 37 degrees Celsius,

370.text: or 98 degrees fahrenheit, I'd keep it at a little less

373.text: than that because that's probably too warm.

376.text: So that led to a very important design decision

378.text: to make it a binary happy face frowning face

383.text: I think that that's really the key to great design,

384.text: is empathy and all of these nuances

390.text: When we needed to do more testing,

392.text: we used our own family members.

395.text: that I stuffed into one of the early prototypes.

400.text: And so it was in this way

401.text: that we tested and retested hundreds of times

404.text: over the course of several years

410.text: I've got it with me here today.

414.text: So this is the Embrace Warmer, as you can see

416.text: it looks like a little sleeping bag

419.text: You've got the clear viewing window here,

421.text: and in the back, you've got this pouch of wax

425.text: that can be melted either with boiling water

428.text: or with a short burst of electricity

430.text: for places that do have intermittent access to electricity.

433.text: And once melted it stays at the exact same temperature

435.text: for up to eight hours at a stretch.

438.text: And this can be reheated thousands of times.

441.text: So you put it into a little pocket in the back

443.text: and it creates a warm microenvironment for the baby.

445.text: I'm going to pass this around so you guys can

447.text: play around with it a bit.

452.text: So I still remember in 2011 as we were launching the product

455.text: in those weeks leading up to our product launch,

458.text: everything that could have possibly gone wrong went wrong.

461.text: The electricity in our manufacturing facility went out

466.text: a part of our product got stuck in customs

470.text: because the wash tags were sewn incorrectly,

473.text: but somehow we managed to get that first product

475.text: ready to ship to our first customer.

478.text: And then on the way to that doctor's office,

483.text: So the whole team jumped out,

484.text: we piled into this auto-rickshaw that you see here,

486.text: and we delivered our first product.

489.text: I always tell the story because it's so representative

491.text: to me of what entrepreneurship is all about,

494.text: which is doing whatever it takes to get past the obstacles

496.text: that come in your way and finally reach that end goal.

502.text: And here is our very first customer.

506.text: The most exciting part of this journey by far,

509.text: has been getting this product into the hands of the families

512.text: and the babies who need it the most.

513.text: And we have been so lucky to get the support

517.text: from people of all different walks of life,

519.text: who really rallied behind us to help make an impact

524.text: Which really led me to believe this quote from

528.text: He says "When you truly believe something,

530.text: "the universe will conspire to help you achieve it."

533.text: A few years ago we were invited to present our work

537.text: to President Obama at the White House,

538.text: and that got great visibility for our efforts.

540.text: We presented a commitment at the Clinton Global Initiative

544.text: as well and formed some great partnerships through that.

546.text: In 2014 Beyonce made a donation to us,

550.text: a surprise donation that got our products

552.text: into nine countries across Sub-Saharan Africa.

555.text: So with the help of all of these people,

557.text: to date we have been able to help over 200,000 babies.

562.text: The product is now in 20 countries,

564.text: and I'd like to share just a few of the stories

575.text: About four years ago we started working with

579.text: A day after we delivered our product,

581.text: they called us telling us they had found

583.text: a two-pound baby that was abandoned

585.text: on a street in central China.

605.text: and it was a very very special experience.

817.text: So it's been incredibly rewarding and exciting to be a part

824.text: But I would be lying if I were to tell you

826.text: that it was all roses and flowers and

828.text: that we didn't face some extreme challenges along the way.

832.text: It's always wonderful to have a vision

833.text: of what you want to do,

838.text: "Everyone has a plan until they get punched in the mouth."

841.text: This has happened to us repeatedly.

843.text: I could tell you about our challenges for days.

847.text: But I'll tell you about one pivotal moment for us

850.text: that really kind of redefined the business,

852.text: and taught me a lot about life as well.

855.text: So in 2014 I had lived in India for four years.

859.text: I moved back to the U.S. and at that time

861.text: we had been working on a global distribution

863.text: and financing deal with a major medical device company.

867.text: I had been working on this deal day and night

870.text: for almost a year at that point,

872.text: and then about a week away from signing the deal,

875.text: we found out that this company let go of their

878.text: healthcare CEO, who was the main advocate for the deal,

881.text: and they pulled the plug on our financing.

884.text: We had seven days of cash left in the bank,

890.text: I had no idea what we gonna do.

891.text: All of us thought we were gonna have to

898.text: I had gone to the World Economic Forum at Davos,

900.text: and one morning I went to a meditation session,

904.text: which maybe five out of 3,000 people showed up for.

907.text: And I happened to sit next to Marc Benioff,

910.text: who is the founder and CEO of Salesforce.

914.text: Marc and I started talking, after the meditation session

918.text: and I shared with him my work at Embrace.

920.text: Coincidentally, he was about to make a donation

923.text: to create the Preterm Birth Initiative at USCF

926.text: in partnership with the Gates Foundation.

929.text: So if there were anything in the world

931.text: that would make me believe in serendipity,

932.text: it was the universe seating me next to this man.

936.text: I kept in touch with Marc, and when this crisis hit,

939.text: I sent him an urgent email telling him

941.text: what had happened, asking for his help.

944.text: John Hennessy was one of our advisors,

946.text: also reached out to Marc asking for his help.

948.text: And a few days later, he wrote back

950.text: generously agreeing to fund the company.

954.text: So I'm just so indebted to Marc for saving the company,

958.text: we would have had to close our doors if it weren't for that.

962.text: And it was a really pivotal experience

965.text: in a number of different ways,

967.text: but one of the things it forced me to do at that point

970.text: was to take a step back and really re-evaluate our strategy.

973.text: You know, at the time we were selling our product

1068.text: So for every Little Lotus that we sell here in the U.S.,

1157.text: So that is my story, that is the last 10 years of my life.

1161.text: And this is where we're at today.

1163.text: And I thought I would end by just sharing a few

1165.text: of the key lessons that I have learned in this journey.

1171.text: So the first lesson is to lead with the WHY.

1173.text: I got this from Simon Sinek's TED talk.

1175.text: If you haven't watched it I really recommend it.

1177.text: Why do you do what you do?

1180.text: And how does this align with your own purpose

1183.text: And this is so much more important than what you do

1187.text: And I think being really rooted in your purpose

1189.text: and being clear about that why,

1191.text: it will get you through your toughest moments

1193.text: and get you through all those obstacles

1197.text: And at the same time it will allow you to inspire others

1199.text: and rally people behind your cause,

1202.text: so give a lot of thought to why it is you want to do

1206.text: My second lesson here, from Winston Churchill who said

1210.text: "Success is not final, failure is not fatal.

1214.text: "It is the courage to continue that counts."

1217.text: And I have a picture of me surfing here,

1218.text: because this is a sport I picked up

1220.text: about a year and a half ago,

1221.text: that I have become completely obsessed with.

1224.text: One of the things about surfing,

1225.text: it's so humbling, because most of the time

1228.text: I'm not on my board, I'm falling off my board,

1230.text: and having to find the courage to get back on,

1233.text: and paddle back out for the next wave.

1235.text: And to me, this is the most important trait

1245.text: And you need to have the courage and that persistence

1247.text: to get back out there, learn from your mistakes,

1251.text: The other, related thing I've learned

1254.text: from surfing and the ocean, is this idea of impermanence.

1258.text: Everything in this world is constantly changing.

1261.text: And nothing teaches you that more than being in the ocean,

1265.text: where your conditions are changing minute to minute,

1268.text: and what that's taught me about

1272.text: to not be attached to anything, including an outcome.

1276.text: I think I had become so attached to this end outcome

1278.text: for Embrace, that the thought of the company

1281.text: shutting down in that story I told you,

1284.text: really threatened my own sense of identity,

1286.text: and what I learned from that process

1289.text: is that we are not defined by our successes or our failures,

1293.text: we are defined by our values

1295.text: and by the journey that we take.

1297.text: So as cliche as it sounds,

1299.text: the journey is truly more important than the destination.

1302.text: Make sure you're having fun in that journey

1308.text: And my last lesson here, is to choose to see the world

1314.text: Because we get to choose the perspective

1315.text: by which we see the world.

1317.text: After living in India for a few years,

1319.text: I could see myself becoming jaded,

1323.text: I was dealing with some of the most vulnerable populations

1326.text: in the world and saw so many sad things.

1330.text: I was working in a very corrupt and broken system.

1332.text: And then at some point I caught myself.

1335.text: I realized that for every horrible thing that I saw,

1337.text: I saw something equally as beautiful.

1341.text: All of the wonderful people who had come together to help us

1343.text: in this cause, all of the noble doctors I met

1345.text: who stayed up all night in these villages to see patients.

1349.text: The most beautiful thing I got to see in my work

1351.text: was a love a parent has for their child.

1355.text: It's the purest and most selfless form of love in the world,

1358.text: and I realized that a mother, no matter how poor

1360.text: or uneducated or impoverished, will do anything

1367.text: And that's the beauty I got to see every day in my work.

1371.text: So I encourage you to see the world

1372.text: through the lens of beauty, because that will give you

1374.text: the optimism to keep changing the world.

1380.text: And I wanted to leave you with one last thought.

1383.text: So this is the Milan Cathedral.

1385.text: The great cathedrals of Europe were built over centuries,

1389.text: this one the construction began in 1385,

1395.text: What that meant is oftentimes the people who

1397.text: spent their whole lives working on these cathedrals

1399.text: never lived to see the fruits of their labor,

1402.text: nor did their children, nor did their grandchildren.

1406.text: So why did they dedicate themselves so tirelessly

1412.text: I believe it was because they believed in a cause

1413.text: that was far greater than themselves.

1417.text: So I ask each of you to think about,

1419.text: what is the cathedral that you want to build?

1421.text: And what is the legacy that you want to leave?

1423.text: My cathedral is a place where no baby dies from being cold.

1429.text: It's a place where every parent is empowered

1431.text: to save their child, and it's a place

1434.text: where the brightest minds come together

1436.text: to change the world for the better.

1438.text: One baby step at a time.
